III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Initial evaluation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12310
Section • (3) The agency shall assess all the following:
Description
• (c) Physical, mental, and emotional health of each
member of the household, including any history of
substance use disorder or treatment.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency licensed a foster home in 2022. One of the foster parents
had substantial mental health history that included, but not limited
to 20 hospitalizations, suicide attempts, and hallucinations. While
the agency did collect self-reported history, they did not do a
thorough background check into this history given its seriousness.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on July 16, 2024.
There was no additional information to add.
Foster Parent 1 & Foster Parent 2 were interviewed face to face
by Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) worker on
June 21, 2024. Their attorney was present via telephone and
advised them not to answer any questions.
DHHS Licensing Supervisor (DHHS LS) was interviewed via
Teams on July 25, 2024. He stated Foster Parent 1 & Foster
Parent 2 have been licensed since April 2022. He stated Foster
Parent 1 has mental health history that includes hospitalizations,
and she was open and honest about this with the agency during
the initial licensing process.
DHHS LS stated during the initial licensing process there were
conversations between he and DHHS Licensing Worker 2
regarding Foster Parent 1’s mental health history. He couldn’t
recall specifics but stated DHHS Licensing Worker 2 would follow
up with Foster Parent 1 and her current mental health providers if
necessary. He stated there was no discussion regarding obtaining
Foster Parent 1’s mental health records but there were items
2

identified in the mental health evaluations that needed follow up
and clarification regarding Foster Parent 1’s audio hallucinations
and therefore, the licensing worker conducted a follow up call to
determine the last time Foster Parent 1 was treated for audio
hallucinations and DHHS Licensing Worker 2 did that. When the
license was issued the email from Department of Child Welfare
Licensing (DCWL) Central Office Licensing Consultant (COLC)
was complimentary regarding Foster Parent 1’s mental health
assessment. He stated based on that feedback they felt they had
done a thorough job.
He stated Foster Parent 1 has mental health history and clarified
the majority of her mental health history was when she was in her
20’s, as reported by Foster Parent 1. The information regarding
her current mental health indicated she would not be a threat and
is appropriate as far as staying on top of her treatment and being
proactive seeking services if needed. He stated he doesn’t have a
background in mental health and felt the statements obtained from
current providers were appropriate and didn’t feel he was in a
position to second guess the professional opinions of mental
health providers. Therefore, mental health records were not
obtained, but the mental health statements from current providers
that mention Foster Parent 1’s history was reviewed.
DHHS LS stated the agency does not have a formal process when
assessing a potential foster parent. He clarified that it is more of a
case-by-case basis since every situation is different. With criminal
history, depending on what it is they would obtain police reports
and any information to make an assessment. He stated they have
reached out to DCWL COLC in the past to inquire if more is
needed and that has been helpful. No case is the same, so the
agency assesses all information gathered and determines if more
is needed. DHHS LS provided additional follow up and stated if he
is uncertain about something he will reference licensing rules, the
technical assistance manual or seek other resources such as
minutes from licensing calls, responses he received for past report
or questions or contact from DCWL COLC.
DHHS Licensing Worker 1 (DHHS LW1) was interviewed via
Teams on July 26, 2024. She stated she was assigned as the
licensing worker for the special investigations. The first one was
regarding concerns that Foster Parent 1’s mental health wasn’t
thoroughly reported and assessed during the initial evaluation.
The second one was regarding a mental health episode Foster
Parent 1 had and if she was fit to continue to be a licensed foster
parent.
3

The first evaluation she completed was regarding Foster Parent
1’s mental health in June 2023. She did a thorough review of the
provider record and the information, documentation and interviews
DHHS Licensing Worker 2 obtained during the initial assessment.
She stated she reviewed updated and new medical and mental
health statements that were completed as part of the adoption
assessment. She also reviewed the mental health records for
Foster Parent 1 that were hundreds of pages and reported she
obtained these from Foster Parent 1. She stated there was some
conflicting information in the records. For example, one record
indicated Foster Parent 1 had a history of physical abuse as a
child and others didn’t state this. Another example, she was
married to a man but actually had a girlfriend. She stated Foster
Parent 1 was very transparent with the extent of her mental health
history, ongoing treatment, medication and therapy during the
initial evaluation and also the special evaluations. Any information
that was not included initially did not appear to be intentional.
DHHS Licensing Worker 2 (DHHS LW2) was interviewed via
Teams on July 30, 2024. She stated she is the assigned licensing
worker for Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2. She completed
the initial home assessment when they were licensed in 2022 and
completed any subsequent reevaluations. She stated Foster
Parent 1 was forthcoming from the beginning regarding her mental
health history and has been consistent with the information
throughout their working relationship. During the initial licensing
process Foster Parent 1 reported she had been hospitalized due
to her mental health approximately 20 times. She provided
information regarding her diagnosis, medications she was taking,
and family history.
DHHS LW2 stated during the initial licensing process she starts
with orientation and informs potential foster parents they will be
discussing medical health and mental health history. She couldn’t
recall exactly but is assuming that is when Foster Parent 1
informed her of her medical and mental health history. She stated
she was initially concerned when Foster Parent 1 informed her of
the number of past hospitalizations due to mental health but
advised most of the hospitalizations occurred when she was in her
early 20’s which was approximately 20 years ago. This was
reported by Foster Parent 1. Her brain was still developing and
getting a handle on her mental health. Later hospitalizations, the
2018 hospitalization for example were more preventative
measures according to her doctors. Foster Parent 1 has had a
good grasp on her mental health since then and is aware when
4

she needs additional help or a medication check and this is also
reported by her doctors.
DHHS LW2 stated she was not concerned regarding Foster
Parent 1 not reporting or under reporting any information
regarding her mental health history because she had obtained
current statements from providers she was working with for a long
time. She stated it’s not required of her to obtain records to
compare them with what was being reported. If she had been
asked by DCWL COLC to obtain more information she would have
but didn’t feel it was necessary based on the information she
already had and the follow up she did with Foster Parent 1 and
her therapist. She felt she had a good grasp with what was going
on with Foster Parent 1.
DHHS LW2 said when she is working on licensing a home and
information is reported, she will follow policy and licensing rules in
regard to when she requests additional information and when she
doesn’t. She stated if someone reports something, and it doesn’t
make sense, or she feels like she isn’t getting enough information,
then she will request additional information.
For mental health their office uses the mental health statement.
She stated if there was something on the mental health statement
that indicated Foster Parent 1 would not be appropriate to care for
foster children from her provider, she would request more
information. She stated their office also follows what is in the
technical assistance manual, licensing rules or any follow up
requested by her supervisor or DCWL. She stated DCWL
complimented her on her assessment of Foster Parent 1’s mental
health history.
DCWL Central Office Program Manager (DCWL COPM) was
interviewed on August 14, 2024. She stated the license for Foster
Parent 1 & 2 was opened in 2022. In reviewing attachments to the
3130 there were multiple practitioners that indicated there were no
barriers that would impact Foster Parent 1’s ability to foster.
DCWL COPM clarified documentation received was from recent
and current practitioners.
The mental health practitioners outlined Foster Parent 1’s history,
not just self-account from Foster Parent 1. The history is
mentioned by two mental health practitioners and her doctor. One
from one inpatient stay in 2018 and one from ongoing the mental
health practitioner for therapeutic services. Ottawa DHHS was
provided clear documentation from practitioners who have
5

ongoing responsibility to assess compliance with treatment and
Foster Parent 1’s benefit from treatment and they assessed her to
be stable.
The 3130 has been updated since this home study and it now has
another area that goes deeper and asks for an explanation for
how the diagnosis presented prior to and after treatment so there
is a clearer picture regarding triggers.
DCWL Central Office Consultant (DCWL COLC) was
interviewed on August 14, 2024. She stated the 3130 was not a
report she had to go back and ask for more documentation. DHHS
LW2 did follow up with a medical doctor to confirm the
schizoaffective as opposed to the bipolar diagnosis and made the
appropriate calls to the doctor to get clarification. DCWL COLC
stated If she sees something that isn’t covered in the medical
statement she will send back and ask for more
information/documentation.
DCWL COLC stated she reviews the social history including
trauma and what is going on regarding what they are saying the
mental health diagnosis is. On technical guidance calls held
monthly regarding the medical/mental health, agencies are asked
to pull records from hospitals.
Compliance was determined from a doctor in a psychiatric
hospital, who was able to give certification going back to 2018 for
Foster Parent 1. When reviewing the form, they said yes to all
areas to applicant being able to process and work with
traumatized children including the licensed social worker doing
current therapeutic sessions with her. One of the things she noted
with Foster Parent 1’s mental health history was that many of the
inpatient mental health hospitalizations occurred during
adolescence through early adulthood. DCWL COLC indicated,
based on information and documentation reviewed, Foster Parent
1 was stabilized and working with mental health providers and
was aware of her diagnoses and things she needs to do that
impacts her diagnosis and ongoing self-care. The doctor who
signed off on the medical went back and made an assessment on
the most recent hospitalization in 2018 and she was able to
understand all the mental health records and gave the actual ok
that Foster Parent 1 could be a foster parent and that is what
DCWL reviewed. One of the considerations from doctors and how
they work through that mental health history is taking into
consideration whether or not the individual is compliant. In this
6

scenario the doctors said yes and there was a plan for how to deal
with her mental health.
The form the doctor completed noted she assessed Foster Parent
1’s history going back through the most recent hospitalization. The
technical guidance DCWL gives is they weigh the medical history
through the past 5 years. DCWL looked at the last 5 years and
gathered documentation for this period and she did not require
them to speak to anything prior. Ottawa contacted Foster Parent
1’s doctor and that is what is required in terms of DCWL weighing
the rules and determining compliance.
There is one mental health statement that mentions her 2018
hospitalization. Another one states her first hospitalization was in
1998 and most recent in 2018. Another mental health statement
reports she was hospitalized approximately 20 times total. The
statements are brief with little detail.
Documents reviewed:
• 3130 completed on 4/18/2022: (reviewed in CWLM &
MISACWIS. The mental health information that is
referenced and uploaded are mental health statements.
There are no mental health records).
Foster Parent 1 receives Social Security Disability due to a
diagnosis of bipolar 1 disorder, unspecified bipolar disorder,
and general anxiety disorder. Medical and mental health
statements were obtained from Foster Parent 1’s providers.
All three providers stated Foster Parent 1 does not have a
physical or mental health condition that would adversely
affect the care of a foster child. Foster Parent 1 shares she
was diagnosed in her early 20s and has learned to manage
her diagnosis effectively with therapy, medications, and
self-care.
Section 9 Health: Both household members are in good
physical, mental, and emotional health currently. Does
anyone in the household have a physical or mental
health diagnosis or condition that would make care of
the child difficult? If so, describe how it may affect the
care of a child. No one in the household has a physical or
mental health diagnosis or condition that would make care
of a foster child difficult.
Medical statements & mental health evaluations.
• On 01/17/2022, a medical statement was completed for
Foster Parent 1 by a Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine (D.O).
The signed statement indicated Foster Parent 1 was
7

treated for diverticulitis in 2009 and 2021, kidney stones in
2019, and depression with hospitalization in 2018 following
her father's death. She is currently being treated for bipolar
and following up with a psychiatrist. The signed statement
indicates that Foster Parent 1 does not require any special
care and does not have a known condition that would
adversely affect the care of a foster child.
• On 01/17/2022, a mental health evaluation was completed
for Foster Parent 1 by a psychiatric hospital. Foster Parent
1 began services in September 2021 and is currently being
seen for Bipolar 1 disorder, unspecified bipolar disorder,
and generalized anxiety disorder. Foster Parent 1 was last
seen on 01/17/2022. Foster Parent 1 was hospitalized for
the above conditions in 1998 and has had approximately 20
hospitalizations. Her last hospital stay was in 2018. To the
best ability, Foster Parent 1 is able to understand,
remember, and carry out short, simple and detailed
instructions; make judgments on simple work-related
decisions; interact appropriately with the public; and
respond to children with empathy and sympathy. It is
believed that Foster Parent 1 is able to appropriately
handle and interact with children who have unique
problems of trauma history and adjustment, impulse
control, ADHD, problems managing aggression and anger,
depression, and medical concerns. It is believed that Foster
Parent 1 can interact appropriately with the public, social,
and health agencies and is able to accept rejection from a
child. The signed statement indicated Foster Parent 1 does
not require any special care and does not have a known
condition that could affect the care of a foster child. Foster
Parent 1 is prescribed medications. It was noted that Foster
Parent 1 experiences the side effect of sleepiness from
nighttime sleep medications.
• On 01/18/2022, a mental health evaluation was completed
for Foster Parent. Foster Parent 1 started this service in
December 2020 and is currently being seen for
schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, and most recent
episode depressed. Foster Parent 1 was last seen on
12/31/2021. Medications are being used as part of her
treatment but are not being prescribed by this agency.
Foster Parent 1 has not reported any side effects. Foster
Parent 1 was hospitalized, in 2018 for a condition in which
she treated Foster Parent 1. Foster Parent 1 is able to
understand, remember, and carry out short, simple and
detailed instructions; make judgments on simple work-
8

related decisions; interact appropriately with the public; and
respond to children with empathy and sympathy. It is
believed that Foster Parent 1 is able to appropriately
handle and interact with children who have unique
problems of trauma history and adjustment, impulse
control, ADHD, problems managing aggression and anger,
depression, and medical concerns. It was assessed that
Foster Parent 1 can interact appropriately with the public,
social, and health agencies and is able to accept rejection
from a child. The signed statement indicated Foster Parent
1 does not require any special care and does not have a
known condition that could affect the care of a foster child.
• On 04/13/2022, a letter was received from a therapist
clarifying Foster Parent 1’s schizoaffective disorder
diagnosis. The diagnosis was in Foster Parent 1's file,
when Foster Parent 1 first started attending this office
several years ago. It is believed the diagnosis of bipolar
disorder is more accurate as, in the therapists observation,
Foster Parent 1 only reports audio hallucinations during
times of mood disturbance/extreme stress.
• On 04/13/2022, a follow up phone call was placed by
DHHS LW2 to determine when the last time was that
Foster Parent 1 experienced audio hallucinations. This
occurred around the time of Foster Parent 1’s stepfather's
hospitalization and death. During this time, Foster Parent 1
also had the additional stress of attending college and
working full time. Foster Parent 1 is very aware of her mood
states and always knows when it's time to seek help
including medication changes, increased counseling, or
other interventions.
• During the home visit on 02/10/2022, Foster Parent 1
stated her hospitalizations, other than the stay in 2018,
were all in her early teens and 20s, when she was still
getting a handle on her diagnosis. She shared that she
admitted herself in 2018, when her stepfather passed
away, more as a precautionary measure due to her past
mental health issues. Foster Parent 1 stated her mental
health is very well managed now, and she plans to continue
counseling and medication management.
• A follow up response was received from Foster Parent 1 on
04/13/2022 indicating that, prior to 2018, Foster Parent 1
was last hospitalized during a particularly stressful time in
her life that also coincided with the loss of her only
remaining ovary and the hormonal changes affected her
and her mental health. She does not remember the exact
date, but believes it was the Spring/Summer of 2010.
9

• On 04/13/2022, a medication list was received for Foster
Parent 1. Foster Parent 1 is prescribed Lorazepam, 1 mg
daily, as needed for anxiety; Valtrex 500 mg, 2 times daily
as needed for cold sores; Wellbutrin 150 mg for seasonal
depression, Foster Parent 1 shared she takes this in the
Winter but does not normally need it in the Spring and
Summer when she can be outdoors more. Seroquel 300
mg daily for bipolar disorder; Lipitor 20mg daily for high
cholesterol.
• Summary of strengths and areas of growth, attention.
LCW 2 has found Foster Parent 1 & 2 to be very loving and
dedicated to each other, their family, and serving others.
They have an adequate understanding of the foster care
process and are willing to work with the agency, the
parents, and the children. Their life experiences, their
willingness to help others, and their dedication to their
family indicates they would have the ability to help a child
understand the dynamics of being fostered and/or adopted
and raised by family. At this time, LCW 2 does not believe
Foster Parent 1 & 2 have any areas of growth that need to
be attended to prior to caring for a child. LCW 2 believes
Foster Parent 1 & 2 are willing, able, and open to learning
and growing as foster parents.
• 1998 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 admitted to a
psychiatric hospital due to confusion, paranoia, auditory
hallucination, including the belief the TV is talking to her,
and anxiety.
• 2006 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 admitted to a
hospital due to paranoia, appetite and severe sleep
changes. Displayed agitation and high stress level.
• 2007 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 admitted to a
psychiatric hospital for inpatient mental health treatment
due to issues with depression and self-harm. Foster Parent
1 also has problems with significant anxiety. She reported a
lengthy history for mood swings, agitation and depression
starting in her teenage years. She reports previous
hospitalization due to auditory hallucinations.
• 2009 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 admitted to a
hospital on 2/9/2009 for inpatient mental health treatment
due to severe anxiety, depression and paranoia.
• 2018 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 admitted to a
psychiatric hospital on 8/16/2018 due to anxiety,
depression, significant decline in functioning, dangerous to
self, others or property. Chief complaint is having a lot of
obsessive thoughts of suicide and then she will be at
10

peace. Foster Parent 1 was admitted to a psychiatric
hospital on 8/24/2018 due to agitation, depression and a
significant decline in functioning.
• 2019 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 has attempted
suicide several times, but her suicide attempts have usually
been associated with auditory hallucinations. Reported
occasional auditory hallucinations in recent months.
• 2023 mental health records. Foster Parent 1 was admitted
to a psychiatric hospital from 8/7/2023-8/14/2023 due to
suicidal ideations and psychotic symptoms. She had
attempted to cut her throat the morning of admittance and
reported regularly occurring auditory hallucinations. Foster
Parent 1 made a statement that Foster Parent 2 was a
“child molester”.
• Partial hospitalization at a psychiatric hospital from
8/15/2023-8/17/2023 due to delusion, paranoia and anxiety.
Foster Parent 1 was admitted to a psychiatric hospital from
8/18/2023-9/5/2023 due to confusion and driving around
without anyone knowing her whereabouts.
• Partial hospitalization at a psychiatric hospital from
10/5/2023-10/19/2023 due to depression and medication
concerns. Notes two recent hospitalizations for mania and
psychosis and primary stressor is foster children being
taken from her home.
• There are no records available for all of Foster Parent 1’s
hospitalizations for various reasons, including the length of
time passed and some facilities have closed.
• Review of additional mental health records for Foster
Parent 1 indicate a consistent history of significant anxiety,
depression, auditory hallucinations, and, at times, suicidal
thoughts.
• Children’s Foster Home Licensing Technical Assistance
(TA) Manual:
When determining the physical, mental, and emotional
health of an applicant/licensee/household member, the
following are to be considered:
• Are they receiving disability? What is the basis for
the disability? What are the limitations they may
have based on that disability and the physician’s
input? Are the limitations of the stated disability
consistent with any known employment? For
example, the disability is for back problems, but the
person has some part time employment that would
typically require lifting.
• Are they prescribed medications? What are the
medications? What do they take them for? Dosage?
11

When do they take them? How often? What are the
side effects? Have they discussed side effects with
their physician? Where are they kept?
• Physical, mental, and emotional effects of
medication or the condition of the person: Do they
impair the ability to provide foster care? If so, who
will be caring for the children during those times?
• Does the diagnosis or prescription prevent
transportation (operating a vehicle)? If so, who will
transport children?
• Compliance with treatment plan for medical/mental
health.
• Are they in counseling/therapy? Documentation from
the current counselor/therapist must be gathered to
determine why they are in treatment. Have they ever
been admitted to the hospital? How are they doing in
treatment? Does the counselor/therapist have any
concerns pertaining to the applicant/licensee
fostering? Do they need a current psychological
assessment?
• June 2018 Foster home licensing monthly teleconference
call notes.
“The challenges, stressors, and history of help-seeking
subsection of the family life section in the 3130 notes that
the applicant or AHHM has previous history of challenges or
help-seeking that include current or past (last 5 years)
inpatient or outpatient therapy/treatment, or that the person
is currently prescribed medication to treat a mental health
issue; however this is not mentioned in the health section of
the 3130 and there is no information or assessment from the
provider/physician, etc.”
• CWL 3500: 3130 Packet Review Tool (for optional use).
Page 4: “Verbal or written report was received from mental
health provider if seen within past 5 years.”
• April 19, 2022, email sent from DCWL COLC to DHS
Licensing supervisor. “Thank you for the through mental
health assessment and review of the medical source
documents and after reviewing them, going back to the
applicant to discuss and to include those assessment and
findings in the evaluation, this is excellent.”
Analysis The agency followed guidance provided during a monthly foster
home licensing teleconference meeting, DCWL 3130 report tool
and feedback provided by DCWL upon submitting the initial
evaluation of Foster Parent 1 & 2. Therefore, there is no citation.
12

Technical Assistance
The agency should ensure that the entirety of someone’s long
mental health history be assessed, not just the recent past.
Records from prior providers, discharge summaries from
hospitalizations, etc. should be requested and reviewed to ensure
proper follow up recommendations were complied with to assess
the long-term stability and adherence to mental health
professional’s advice.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code License recommendation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325
Section • (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
Description appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained
in the foster home evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Special evaluation findings are not consistent with the facts.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on July 16, 2024.
There was no additional information to add.
DHHS Licensing supervisor (DHHS LS) was interviewed via
Teams on July 25, 2024. He stated foster parents have been
licensed since April 2022. He stated Foster Parent 1 has mental
health history that includes hospitalizations, and she was open
and honest about this from the start of the licensing process.
He stated there were concerns regarding Foster Parents 1 & 2
calling D.A Blodgett (DAB) too often. He stated once the case
moved to adoption there were concerns reported. He stated, in
general, there seems to be some differences between foster care
and adoption in terms of foster parents being appropriate for
placement, but questions arose once it moved to adoption.
He stated his office opened two special investigations based on
concerns reported. The first one in June 2023 was regarding, in
part, concerns about the number of medical appointments for
13

children who were placed in their home at the time and also
Foster Parent 1’s mental health. He stated D.A Blodgett requested
a meeting and he had the impression they wanted to interrogate
so he requested their questions in advance to be prepared with
responses. Based on those concerns Ottawa DHHS opened a
special investigation. He stated Foster Parent 1 completed a
parenting assessment and a psychological evaluation. He stated
he believed she did this in response to the concerns brought up by
DA Blodgett. DA Blodgett also brought up concerns regarding
items contained in Foster Parent 1’s mental health records were
entirely consistent with the information Foster Parent 1 provided
during the initial licensing process. DHHS LS stated there were
also some inconsistencies within the mental health records that
don’t appear to apply to Foster Parent 1. He provided an example
where it was documented Foster Parent 1 was previously married
and had a baby and neither were accurate. He stated the second
special investigation in October 2023 was due to concerns of
Foster Parent 1’s mental health and a statement she made
accusing Foster Parent 2 of being a child molester. He stated they
were forthcoming about updating the agency on what is taking
place.
They were found in compliance with both investigations. He
stated, in general, he will review and if additional information or
clarification is needed, he will go back to the worker. If a narrative
is provided and gives rise to more questions, then follow up is
needed to address the questions. He stated the issues regarding
Foster Parent 1’s mental health issues were a little more difficult
due to being less concrete. He stated he felt DHHS LW1 was
thorough and detail oriented.
DHHS Licensing Worker 1 (LW1) was interviewed via Teams on
July 26, 2024. She stated she was assigned as the licensing
worker for the special investigations. The first one was regarding
concerns that Foster Parent 1’s mental health wasn’t thoroughly
reported and assessed during the initial evaluation. The second
one was regarding a mental health episode Foster Parent 1 had
and if she was fit to continue to be a licensed foster parent. She
stated the concerns regarding the number of medical
appointments for foster children who were previously placed in the
home was not part of the investigations she completed.
She stated the communication between DA Blodgett was not
consistent with Foster Parents 1 & 2. She stated at one point DA
Blodgett said Foster Parents 1 & 2 were communicating too often
and then they had concerns they weren’t communicating enough.
14

Her understanding is the number of medical appointments were
not related to concerns with Foster Parent 1’s mental health. She
stated her understanding was DA Blodgett was missing some of
the documentation from the appointments that occurred, and they
questioned a diagnosis. They questioned the number of
appointments, but it wasn’t correlated to Foster Parent 1’s mental
health.
The first evaluation she completed was regarding Foster Parent
1’s mental health. She did a thorough review of the provider
record and the information, documentation and interviews DHHS
LW2 obtained during the initial assessment. She stated she
reviewed updated and new medical and mental health statements
that were completed as part of the adoption assessment. She also
reviewed the mental health records for Foster Parent 1 that were
hundreds of pages. She stated there was some conflicting
information in the records. For example, one record indicated
Foster Parent 1 had a history of physical abuse as a child and
others didn’t state this. Another example, she was married to a
man but actually had a girlfriend.
She stated Foster Parent 1 was very transparent with the extent of
her mental health history, ongoing treatment, medication and
therapy during the initial evaluation and also the special
evaluations. Any information that was not included initially did not
